# Definition {#definition .unnumbered}

A function $f$ is continuous at $a$ if for every $\varepsilon > 0$ there exists $\delta > 0$ such that if $|x-a|<\delta$ then $|f(x)-f(a)|<\varepsilon$.

# Example {#example .unnumbered}

Show $f(x)=3x+1$ is continuous at any $a$.

Let $\varepsilon>0$. Choose $\delta=\varepsilon/3$. If $|x-a|<\delta$, then $$|f(x)-f(a)| = |3x+1-(3a+1)| = 3|x-a| < 3\delta = \varepsilon.$$
